FacilityName: Sunoco Partners Mktg. & Terminals Star NC Terminal

_accidents.CI_OtherType: All changes are on the contract operator side

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Star, NC Butane Transloading

RMP EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



Sunoco Partners Marketing & Terminals (SPM&T) Star Terminal was constructed in accordance with the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA Code) #58 (2004 Edition) for Liquified Petroleum Gas Storage, and it is the facility's policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws/codes.



Star Terminal is a Butane transloading facility (specifically, railcar to truck tanker via a portable transloader).  This Risk Management Program (RMP) covers the butane transfer systems only, including the associated piping and up to thirty (30)  storage tanks detached railcars (approximately 33,600 gallon railcars).



Two requirements of this section specifically apply to operations at the Facility:

1. Purpose and General Duty Clause - The essence of the general duty clause is that an owner/operator that stores and uses hazardous chemicals in any quantity has a fundamental obligation to ensure a safe operation and to have plans in place in the event of an accident to appropriately manage the situation.

SPM&T is committed to ensuring the safe operation of the Facility, as well as all of its other operations, to ensure a safe workplace for employees and a safe location for neighbors in the community. SPM&T has procedures in place to prevent accidents and is committed to emergency preparedness both for the Facility and community-wide and coordinates with the Washington Fire Department.



2. Risk Management Plan - The primary function of the Facility is to act as a flammable liquid storage and distribution facility. Due to

the flammable effects associated with butane, it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions to prevent unnecessary human

exposure, to reduce the threat to employee health, and to minimize the threat and impact to nearby members of the community.

The Facility is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety and health. Safety at the Facility depends on the

manner

in which flammable substances are handled as well as the various safety devices incorporated into the design of the

processes. Furthermore, comprehensive training is provided to employees and contractors which reinforces the safety policies and

procedures of the Facility. Programs have been established to help prevent any accidental releases and to train personnel for

emergency response in the event of a release.



SPM&T has implemented safety precautions and procedures designed to prevent and mitigate catastrophic releases. SPM&T has active operating, maintenance, training and inspection procedures. Sunoco provides annual emergency response training to its employees. 

SPM&T's management is committed to the following:

- Preventing accidents;

- Training our employees in correct response procedures in the event of an accident;

- Participating in community emergency preparedness;

- Addressing any citizen concerns by fully explaining potential hazards associated with SPM&T operations and all steps being taken

to prevent and mitigate accidents; and

- Being a good corporate citizen in Wilkes County



Star Terminal complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) Accident Prevention Rules (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D), the Occupational Safety & Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR Part 1910.119) along with its fourteen (14) compliance elements, and all applicable state and local laws and regulations.  The Butane transloading system is designed, constructed and maintained in accordance with NFPA #58, manufacturer's instructions and Energy Transfer specifications.  Railcars meet the U.S. Department of Transportation Federal Railroad Administration design requirements for pressurized tank cars. 



In the event of an emergency involving the Star Terminal's Butane transloading system, it is the policy of the facility to initially contact the Star Volunteer Fire Department and request their assistance.  The facili

ty has no trained fire brigade or hazardous material response team, but outside services may be called in to assist.  The facility emergency response plans are coordinated with the fire departments (alternate fire departments include Biscoe and Troy) and the Montgomery LEPC.  The Star Volunteer Fire Department is aware of the system, available protection systems (site fire extinguishers, emergency shut-off devices) and Emergency Response Procedures at the facility.  The Star Transloading facility is a non-responding facility.



This facility is owned by SPM&T, however the transloading equipment is operated by Hilco, a contract operator.  



This facility had one reportable accidental release in the past 5 years involving a contractor that was operating the transloading equipment.  The release was approximately 1,000 gallons of butane.  No one offsite was injured or evacuated. 



In an effort to improve and promote system safety, Sunoco Partners Marketing & Terminals looks for and seeks employee input on process safety improvements.  Additionally, the Star Volunteer Fire Department is contacted regarding participation in site emergency response drills which involve potential releases.   The contract company that performs thewashin transload operations at the facility is working to improve its training program, and will include more management oversight going forward. 



With these objectives in mind, the Risk Management Plan has been developed to provide information regarding the management of the risks associated with the flammable substance storage process. Above all, SPM&T stresses its commitment to ensuring a safe working environment for employees, visitors and the community.
